ğŸ“– Vol 3: Disciplining the Soul
And that which necessitates faith in this matter from the Quran, the Sunnah, and the sayings of the scholars is too numerous to enumerate. Allah the Exalted said: 'And he who restrains the Soul (Nafs) from desire (Hawa), then Paradise is the abode.' And He the Exalted said: 'Those are the ones whose hearts Allah has tested for piety (Taqwa).' It is said: He extracted from them the love of desires. And the Prophet (peace be upon him) said: 'The believer is between five hardships: a believer who envies him, a hypocrite who hates him, an unbeliever who fights him, a devil who misguides him, and a soul (Nafs) that contends with him.' [43] Thus, he clarified that the soul (Nafs) is a contending enemy that must be struggled against.

Accountability is sometimes after action and sometimes before it for warning. Allah the Exalted said: 'And know that Allah knows what is in your souls (Anfusikum), so beware of Him.' This is for the future. And every looking into quantity and measure to know increase and decrease, then it is called accountability. So the looking at what is before the servant during his day to know his increase from his decrease is from accountability. And Allah the Exalted has said: 'O you who have believed, when you go forth in the path of Allah, then verify.' And He said: 'O you who have believed, if there comes to you a wicked person with information, then verify.' And He said: 'And We have certainly created man and know what his soul (Nafs) whispers to him.' Mentioning that as a warning and alerting to guard against it in the future.

a.g: And know that among you is the Messenger of Allah. If he were to obey you in much of the matter, you would be in difficulty, but Allah has endeared to you the faith and has made it pleasing in your hearts and has made hateful to you disbelief, defiance and disobedience. Those are the [rightly] guided.
[It is] as bounty from Allah and favor. And Allah is Knowing and Wise.

And if two factions among the believers should fight, then make settlement between the two. But if one of them oppresses the other, then fight against the one that oppresses until it returns to the ordinance of Allah. And if it returns, then make settlement between them in justice and act justly. Indeed, Allah loves those who act justly.

The eleventh affliction: Mockery and derision. And this is forbidden however harmful it may be, as Allah the Exalted said: "O you who have believed, let not a people ridicule [another] people; perhaps they may be better than them; nor let women ridicule [other] women; perhaps they may be better than them." And the meaning of mockery is belittling, contempt, and pointing out faults and deficiencies in a manner that causes laughter from it: and that may be through imitation in action and speech, and it may be through indication and gesture, and if it is in the presence of the one being mocked, it is not called backbiting, yet it contains the meaning of backbiting. Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, said: I imitated a person, so the Prophet ï­¬ said to me: "By Allah, I do not love that I imitated a person and I have such and such." And Ibn Abbas said regarding His saying the Exalted: "Woe to us! What is with this Book that leaves nothing small or great but it has enumerated it?" Indeed, the small is smiling in mockery of the believer, and the great is loud laughter at that. And this is an indication that laughing at people is among the sins and major sins. And from Abdullah ibn Zam'ah that he said: I heard the Messenger of Allah ï­¬ while he was preaching, and he admonished them regarding their laughing at flatulence, so he said: "Why does one of you laugh at what he does?" The examination of it is lengthy, so let us first mention the condemnation of backbiting and what has come regarding it from the evidences of the Sacred Law (Sharia). Indeed, Allah the Exalted has explicitly stated its condemnation in His Book and likened its practitioner to an eater of carrion, for He the Most High said: "And do not backbite one another. Would one of you like to eat the flesh of his brother dead? So you would detest it." And the Prophet (peace be upon him) said: "Every Muslim is inviolable to another Muslim: his blood, his wealth, and his honor." And backbiting pertains to honor, and Allah has combined it with wealth and blood.

ğŸ“– Vol 4: Fear and Hope
And indeed, God-Consciousness (Taqwa) is an expression of restraint due to fear as previously mentioned, and therefore Allah the Exalted said: 'Indeed, the most noble of you with Allah is the most God-Conscious (Atqakum) among you.' And therefore, Allah the Exalted enjoined the former and the latter with God-Consciousness (Taqwa), so He said: 'And We have enjoined upon those who were given the Scripture before you and upon you that you fear Allah.' And He the Mighty and Majestic said: 'And fear Me, if you should be believers.' So He commanded fear and made it obligatory and stipulated it in faith, therefore it is inconceivable that a believer be free from fear even if weak, and the weakness of his fear is according to the weakness of his knowledge and faith. And the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said regarding the virtue of God-Consciousness (Taqwa): 'When Allah gathers the former and the latter for an appointed day, then they hear a voice that the farthest among them hears just as the nearest hears, and He says: O people, I have indeed listened to you since I created you until this day of yours, so listen to Me today. Indeed, it is your deeds that are returned to you. O people, I have indeed made lineage and you have made lineage, so you have lowered My lineage and raised your lineage. I said: "Indeed, the most noble of you with Allah is the most God-Conscious (Atqakum) among you." And you refused except to say: So-and-so son of so-and-so and so-and-so is richer than so-and-so. So today I lower your lineage and raise My lineage. Where are the God-Conscious (Muttaqun)?' Then a banner is raised for the people, and the people follow their banner to their dwellings, and they enter Paradise without reckoning.'

Therefore, Allah the Exalted said: "O people, indeed We created you from a male and a female" meaning there is no disparity in your lineages due to your gathering in a single origin. Then He mentioned the benefit of lineage, saying: "and made you peoples and tribes that you may know one another." Then He clarified that nobility is through God-consciousness (Taqwa) not through lineage, saying: "Indeed, the most noble of you in the sight of Allah is the most righteous of you." And when it was said to the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him): 'Who is the noblest of people? Who is the wisest of people?' [92] And indeed, this verse was revealed when Bilal gave the call to prayer (Adhan) on the Kaaba on the Day of Conquest: Al-Harith ibn Hisham, Suhayl ibn Amr, and Khalid ibn Asid said: 'This black slave gives the call to prayer on the Kaaba?' So Allah the Exalted said: "Indeed, the most noble of you in the sight of Allah is the most righteous of you." And the Prophet (peace be upon him) said: "Indeed, Allah has removed from you the boastful pride of the Age of Ignorance (Jahiliyyah) - meaning its major aspect - all of you are children of Adam, and Adam was from dust." [93] And the Prophet (peace be upon him) said: "O assembly of Quraysh, do not come to the people with deeds on the Day of Resurrection while you bring the worldly life carrying it on your necks, saying: 'O Muhammad, O Muhammad,' so I will say like this - meaning I will turn away from you [94] - thus clarifying that if they incline towards the worldly life, their lineage of Quraysh will not benefit them."

And if he follows his ancestors, then what was from their character traits was not pride but rather fear and contempt for the Soul (Nafs) and magnifying the creation and blaming the Soul (Nafs). And indeed they were ennobled by obedience and knowledge and praiseworthy qualities, not by lineage, so let him ennoble himself with what they ennobled themselves. The fourth is pride in noble lineage, like the pride of the Hashimites, to the extent that some think they will be saved by the nobility of their lineage and the salvation of their forefathers, and that they are forgiven, and some imagine that all creation are his masters and slaves. Its remedy is that he should know that however much he opposes his forefathers in their actions and character traits and thinks he is attached to them, he has indeed been ignorant. And if he follows his forefathers, then what was from their character traits was not pride but rather fear and contempt for the Soul (Nafs) and magnifying the creation and blaming the Soul (Nafs). And indeed they were ennobled through obedience and knowledge and praiseworthy qualities, not through lineage, so let him ennoble himself with what they ennobled themselves. And those who did not believe in Allah and the Last Day equaled them in lineage and shared with them in the tribes, and they were, with Allah, worse than dogs and more base than pigs. Therefore, Allah the Exalted said: 'O mankind, indeed We have created you from a male and a female' meaning there is no disparity in your lineages due to your gathering in a single origin. Then He mentioned the benefit of lineage, saying: 'and made you peoples and tribes that you may know one another.' Then He clarified that nobility is through God-consciousness (Taqwa) not through lineage, saying: 'Indeed, the most noble of you with Allah is the most God-conscious (Atqakum) of you.' And when it was said to the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him): 'Who are the noblest of people? Who are the most prudent of people?' He did not say: 'He who traces his lineage to me,' but said: 'The noblest among them are those who remember death most and are most prepared for it.'[92] And indeed this verse was revealed when Bilal gave the call to prayer on the Ka'bah on the Day of Conquest: So Al-Harith ibn Hisham, Suhayl ibn 'Amr, and Khalid ibn Asid said: 'This black slave gives the call to prayer on the Ka'bah?' So Allah the Exalted said: 'Indeed, the most noble of you with Allah is the most God-conscious (Atqakum) of you.' As for the difference, it is that faith (Iman) is made to mean affirmation (Tasdiq) with the heart (Qalb) only, which conforms to the language, and Islam is made to mean outward submission (Taslim), which also conforms to the language. For submission in some places of submission is applied to it the name submission, so it is not a condition for obtaining the name that the meaning be general to every place where the meaning can exist. For whoever touches another with some part of his body is called a toucher even if it does not encompass all of his body. So applying the name Islam to outward submission when there is no submission of the inner self (Batin) is consistent with the tongue (Lisan). And upon this aspect proceeds His saying, the Exalted: 'The Bedouins said, "We have believed." Say, "You have not [yet] believed; but say [instead], 'We have submitted,'"' and His saying, peace be upon him, in the hadith of Sa'd ('or Muslim') because he preferred one over the other, and he intends by the difference the superiority of the two named things.

As for the difference, it is in His saying, the Exalted: 'The Bedouins said, "We have believed." So He intended by faith (Iman) here only the affirmation (Tasdiq) with the heart (Qalb), and by Islam the outward submission (Istislam) with the tongue (Lisan) and limbs (Jawarih). And in the hadith of Gabriel, peace be upon him, when he asked him about faith (Iman), he said: 'That you believe in Allah, His angels, His books, His messengers, the Last Day, and resurrection after death, and the accounting, and the decree (Qadr), its good and its evil.' And in the hadith about Sa'd that he, peace be upon him, gave a man a gift and did not give another. So Sa'd said to him: 'O Messenger of Allah, you left so-and-so, you did not give him, and he is a believer (Mu'min).' So he, peace be upon him, said: 'Or a Muslim (Muslim).' The third aspect: its basis is doubt and its meaning is 'I am truly a believer if Allah wills' since Allah the Exalted said to a specific group by their individuals: 'Those are the true believers' {} so they divided into two categories, and this returns to doubt in the perfection of faith (Iman) not in its foundation, and every person doubts in the perfection of his faith (Iman), and that is not disbelief (Kufr). Doubt in the perfection of faith (Iman) is true from two aspects: one of them from the perspective that hypocrisy (Nifaq) removes the perfection of faith (Iman) and it is hidden, one cannot ascertain freedom from it. The second: that it is perfected by acts of obedience (Taat) and one does not know their existence in perfection. As for the action, Allah the Exalted said: 'Only the believers (Muminun) are those who believe in Allah and His Messenger, then they do not doubt and strive (Jahadu) with their wealth and their selves (Anfus) in the path of Allah. Those are the truthful ones (Sadiqun).' {} So doubt is in this truthfulness (Sidq). And similarly Allah the Exalted said: 'But righteousness (Birr) is from one who believes in Allah and the Last Day and the angels and the Book and the prophets.' {} So He conditioned twenty descriptions like fulfilling the covenant and patience (Sabr) in hardships, then Allah the Exalted said: 'Those are the ones who are truthful (Sadaqu).' {} And Allah the Exalted said: 'Allah raises those who have believed among you and those who were given knowledge degrees.' {} And Allah the Exalted said: 'Not equal among you are those who spent before the conquest and fought.' {} The verse. And Allah the Exalted said: 'They are degrees with Allah.' {} And the Prophet ï·º said: 'Faith (Iman) is naked and its garment is piety (Taqwa)' the hadith, and the Prophet ï·º said: 'Faith (Iman) has seventy-some branches, the lowest of them is removing harm from the path.' So this is what indicates the connection of the perfection of faith (Iman) with actions. As for its connection with freedom from hypocrisy (Nifaq) and hidden polytheism (Shirk), his ï·º saying: 'Four traits, whoever has them is a pure hypocrite (Munafiq) even if he fasts and prays and claims he is a believer (Mumin): when he speaks he lies, when he promises he breaks it, when he is entrusted he betrays, and when he disputes he acts immorally.' And in some narrations: 'and when he makes a covenant he betrays.' And in the hadith of Abu Sa'id al-Khudri: 'Hearts (Qulub) are four: a heart that is bare and in it is a lamp that shines, that is the heart (Qalb) of the believer (Mumin); and a heart that is plated, in it is faith (Iman) and hypocrisy (Nifaq), so the likeness of faith (Iman) in it is like a plant that fresh water nourishes, and the likeness of hypocrisy (Nifaq) in it is like an ulcer that pus and pus nourishes.'

And the Quran has pointed to these character traits in the descriptions of the believers, so the Exalted said: "Indeed, the believers are those who have believed in Allah and His Messenger, then have not doubted, and have struggled with their wealth and their selves in the path of Allah. And the utmost wisdom (Hikmah) and struggling with wealth is generosity (SakhÄ') which returns to controlling the power of desire (Shahwah). Indeed, Allah the Exalted described the Companions saying: "Severe against the disbelievers, merciful among themselves," pointing to that severity has its place and mercy has its place, so perfection is not in severity in every situation nor in mercy in every situation. So this is the explanation of the meaning of character and its goodness and ugliness, and the explanation of its pillars, fruits, and branches.

And everyone who believes in Allah the Exalted and in His attributes and actions something contrary to what He is, whether by imitation (taqlid) or by opinion-based reasoning (ra'y) and speculation, is in this danger, and asceticism (zuhd) and righteousness (salah) are not sufficient to repel this danger. Rather, nothing saves from it except true belief, and the simple-minded (buhl) are safe from this dangerâ€”I mean those who believed in Allah and His Messenger and the Last Day with a comprehensive, firm faith (iman), like the Bedouins, the common people of the Sawad region, and other ordinary folk who did not delve into investigation and speculation, did not independently engage in discourse, and did not incline to the various theologians in imitating their differing statements. Therefore, he (the Prophet) said: 'Most of the people of Paradise are the simple-minded [107].' Therefore, the predecessors (salaf) prohibited investigation, speculation, delving into theological discourse, and probing into these matters, and they commanded the creation to limit themselves to believing in all that Allah the Exalted has revealed and in everything that came from the apparent meanings (zawahir) while believing in the negation of anthropomorphism (tashbih), and they forbade them from delving into interpretation (ta'wil) because the danger in investigating the attributes is great, its obstacles are formidable, its paths are rugged, and intellects are deficient in comprehending the majesty of Allah the Exalted. And the guidance of Allah the Exalted with the light of certainty (yaqin) is veiled from the hearts (qulub) due to what they are created with of love for the worldly life (dunya). What the investigators mention with the merchandise of their intellects is confused and contradictory, and the hearts are accustomed to and attached to what was cast into them at the beginning of creation. And the raging fanaticisms among the creation are nails confirming the inherited beliefs or those taken with good assumption from the teachers at first. Then, the dispositions are infatuated with love for the worldly life, inclined toward it, and the desires of the worldly life take hold of them with their suffocation and divert from complete thought. So if the door of discourse about Allah and His attributes is opened with opinion and speculation...

ğŸ“– Vol 4: Intention, Sincerity, and Truthfulness
The sixth truthfulness (Sidq), which is the highest of the degrees and the most precious, is truthfulness in the stations (Maqamat) of the religion, such as truthfulness in fear (Khawf), hope (Raja'), veneration (Ta'zim), asceticism (Zuhd), contentment (Rida), reliance (Tawakkul), love (Hubb), and the rest of these matters. For these matters have beginnings from which the name is launched by their appearance, then they have ends and realities (Haqa'iq). And the truthful (Sadiq) verifier (Muhaqqiq) is the one who attains their reality. And when a thing prevails and its reality is complete, its possessor is called truthful in it, as it is said: 'So-and-so was truthful in fighting (Qital),' and it is said: 'This is the truthful fear (Khawf), and this is the truthful desire (Shahwah).' And Allah the Exalted said: 'Indeed, the believers are those who have believed in Allah and His Messenger and then do not doubt...' to His saying: '...those are the truthful ones (Sadiqun).' And He the Exalted said: (But righteousness is [in] one who believes in Allah, the Last Day... to His saying... those are the ones who have been truthful). And Abu Dharr was asked about faith (Iman), so he recited this verse. It was said to him: 'We asked you about faith.' He said: 'I asked the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, about faith, and he recited this verse.' And let us strike an example for fear: There is no servant who believes in Allah and the Last Day except that he fears Allah with a fear upon which the name is launched, but it is a fear that is not truthful, meaning it does not reach the degree of reality. Do you not see him when he fears a ruler or a highway robber on his journey, how his color pales and his limbs tremble, and his life becomes bitter, and his eating and sleeping become difficult, and his thought becomes divided until his family and children do not benefit from him, and he may be agitated away from his homeland, exchanging familiarity for loneliness and ease for fatigue, hardship, and exposure to dangers, all of that out of fear of encountering the dreaded thing? Then, he fears the Fire, yet nothing of that appears upon him when a sin flows upon him. And for that reason, he, peace and blessings be upon him, said: 'I have not seen anything like the Fire whose fleer sleeps, nor like Paradise whose seeker sleeps.' The hadith 'I have not seen anything like the Fire whose fleer sleeps' has preceded. So, verification (Tahqiq) in these matters is very rare, and there is no end to these stations until their perfection is attained, but every servant has a share according to his state, either weak or strong.
